item.description:
Abstract Modular (-)operads provide a (coherent) algebraic way to encode the gluing operations of connected surfaces. In particular, the bordism ()-category provides a special kind of modular operad whose algebras are topological field theories, where taking algebras in the symmetric monoidal -category of -linear categories recovers Segal's notion of modular functors, used in his approach to conformal field theories. If instead the algebras are taken in the derived category of chain complexes over , then one obtains a structure closely related to Witten's notion of cohomological field theories. In this talk we aim to provide an example driven introduction to modular (-)operads and their appearance in the study of topological field theories. Goal: Provide an example driven introduction to modular -operads in the study of TFTs using the language of Segal conditions.In this talk we aim to provide an example driven introduction to modular -operads and their application in the study of TFTs. In order to accomplish this we use the language of Segal conditions for -operads, which provides an elegant generalization to modular and cyclic -operads. In this note we aim to provide a more formal introduction to the theory of vector bundles on smooth manifolds following Chapter 10 in Lee's Smooth Manifolds[1]. This work generalizes the theory of the tangent bundle on manifolds.Consider a topological space throughout.Vector Bundle A real vector bundle of rank over is a topological space together with a surjective continuous map satisfying the following conditions: For each , the fiber over is endowed with the structure of a -dimensional vector space. For each , there exists a neighborhood of in and a homeomorphism , called a local trivialization of over , satisfying (i.e. is a bundle map over ) For each , the restriction is an isomorphism of vector spaces. The space is called the total space of the bundle, is called its base, and is its projection.
Note that a real vector bundle is precisely a locally trivial fibration (c.f.
